title.narrative: Local Empowerment for Government Inclusion and Transparency (LEGIT)

description.narrative: (Liberia): .The Local Empowerment for Government Inclusion and Transparency (LEGIT) activity is increasing accountability, transparency, and effectiveness of sub-national government resources in Liberia. LEGIT has four objectives: 1) to increase the capacity of GOL institutions to make incremental and sustained progress in the implementation of the National Policy on Decentralization and Local Governance; 2) to improve the performance and strengthen the capacity of county administrations to coordinate and provide oversight of GOL activities across sectors; 3) to improve the capacity of cities to manage resources and deliver key services; and 4) to increase citizen representation in planning and decision-making in counties and cities. ..With FY 2019 funds, LEGIT will work with GOL institutions to develop and operationalize an implementation plan for the Local Government Act, which was signed into law on September 19, 2018. LEGIT will also improve processes for (a) inter-governmental communication and coordination, (b) citizen engagement, (c) sub-national planning and financial management, and (d) local government participatory planning, revenue generation, budgeting, and service delivery. This activity supports efforts to finance Liberia's Journey to Self-Reliance by improving the capacity of cities to manage resources, develop sub-national planning, and improve financial management in the areas of revenue generation and budgeting....

Objectives for Liberia: The Local Empowerment for Government Inclusion and Transparency (LEGIT) program seeks to increase accountability, transparency, and effectiveness with respect to sub-national government resources in Liberia. LEGIT will provide support to the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Governance Commission as they lead, monitor, and coordinate the implementation of the Government’s decentralization agenda. LEGIT will also strengthen subnational institutions in at least three counties and three cities so that they can be more transparent and responsive to citizens with respect to information on how public resources are used at sub-national levels.
